subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Is this group defunct?
msgSnippet: Actually, there are 470 people who are currently members of the group.  The members of this group do not seem much interested in talking about the design of
messageBody:
Actually, there are 470 people who are currently members of the group.  The members of this group do not seem much interested in talking about the design of Read_Alphabet or other esoteric matters.  I think they are more interested in the use of an efficient alternative to traditional orthography (TO).  So the number of members continues to slowly grow.  I think they learn the alphabet and then use it for school and work notes, and for other personal uses which don't involve other people reading what they have written.

For example, I have been using Quikscript (the name given to the alphabet by its creator, Kingsley Read) for  personal use for more than 40 years.  QS can function as a code to some extent due to the average person having no clue what it is or means.  So if you want to keep something confidential, write it in QS, and it will keep a casual observer from reading what you have written.

Obviously, the intent of a better alphabet for English is not to keep it confidential but to spread knowledge about it far and wide in the hopes that more and more people will use it.  Its dissemination has proven difficult to accomplish, however.  The vast majority of people who have learned TO have little impetus to learn a competing system, even if is it is more efficient.  For another example of this mindset, think of the eagerness with which the U.S. population has clamored to adopt the metric system.

I would like to see this group grow and spread the knowledge and interest in QS to all English speaking countries.  As English becomes more widespread, we need a better alphabet for numerous reasons.  The shortcoming of English spelling is a real detriment to learning the language both for native speakers and those who come to it as a second language.

If anyone has any ideas about making QS more interesting to the general public, speak up!

Paige Gabhart
